note.p: While Ruskin did not subdivide his list into clusters, his intention is evident in that he drafted poems, which correspond to the titles, as an identically ordered sequence in MS VIII. (One cannot tell from the list whether its titles refer to individual poems, as drafted in MS VIII, or to proposed composite sections, of which those poems would have formed a part—the list providing no indication of intended genres.) The first title in this conjectural cluster, “Passing the Alps”, was drafted elsewhere, in MS IA, g.2, probably but not certainly prior to the MS VIII draft sequence.
As discussed in the contextual glosses for “Passing the Alps”, the planned sequence reveals the influence of Samuel Rogersʼs Italy, which (in the 1830 version) has this sequence of poems:

Comparing Rogersʼs sequence with Ruskinʼs, one sees that the younger poetʼs “Passing the Alps” serves the function of Rogersʼs “The Alps”, although Ruskin situates his poem as an introduction to the mountain‐pass sequence, rather than as reflective recollection, as Rogers does in his poem. In Rogersʼs “The Alps”, the narrator reflects on history, including Hannibalʼs crossing the Alps, which Turner made the subject of his vignette for the poem in the 1830 edition of Italy, and which Ruskin likewise developed as the topic of his poem. Rogers begins his poem with a reflection, however, which Ruskin separates out and makes the subject of its own poem—the first sighting of the Alps from Schaffhausen, celebrated in “There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”] (see the latter poemʼs contextual notes, for Ruskinʼs allusion to Rogersʼs lines in “The Alps”, commemorating the first view).

According to Ruskinʼs Plan for Continuation of the Account of a Tour on the Continent, his grand scheme was to place the topic of the first sighting of the Alps in one or both of two items, “Schaffhausen” and “The Alps”, which fall amid a sequence of items leading up to the Splügen Pass crosssing, treating sites from Strasbourg to Constance (see the contextual glosses for “Passing the Alps”). Most of these pieces were never composed, or do not survive, but in MS VIII he composed an untitled poem, which in its content clearly corresponds to either of two proposed items—“There is a charmed peace that aye” [“The Alps from Schaffhausen”]. In MS VIII, this draft poem immediately precedes the draft for “Via Mala”. Thus, in practice, Ruskin thought of his writing about the first sighting of the Alps as immediately preliminary to the writing about crossing the mountains, but he steadily expanded what Rogers treats as a single arc, with the narrator alternating between the time of present viewing and recollected time, both of his own recent past and of history and story. Ruskin tends, in contrast, to string out the narratorʼs experience as a succession of real‐time observations, each stage represented in a separate poem; and he attenuated that string of observations by adding more proposed sites for poems (or prose pieces, or composites) in that part of his Plan for Continuation of the “Account”.

“I thought as, by the cross I past / Of far Helvellyns dreary waste / Mid my own hills, and legend strange” (MS VIII; Works [1903])—The Alpine memorial crosses placed in memory of travelers who met with accidents put Ruskin in mind of a Lake District tourist, Charles Gough, who fell to his death in 1805, when attempting to traverse Mount Helvellyn. He apparently lost his footing when attempting to cross Striding Edge, and his body ended among the rocks below, near Red Tarn, where his remains were found three months later, still being watched over by his terrier, Foxey. The incident achieved near legendary status owing to the dogʼs perceived loyalty. Poems in the epitaph tradition were composed about the story by Wordsworth (“Fidelity”) and by Scott (“Hellvellyn”). (see Ruskin, Works, 1:416 n. 2; 340).

As an available source for Ruskinʼs version of the story, Scottʼs “Hellvellyn” could be found in volume 6 (1833) of the 12‐volume Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott (pp. 370–73), illustrated by Turner, and published by Cadell as an extension of the magnum opus edition (see Millgate, Scottʼs Last Edition, 47–48; see also Dearden, The Library of John Ruskin, 309 [no. 2428]). Wordsworthʼs “Fidelity” was available in volume 4 of the 5‐volume Poetical Works of William Wordsworth (pp. 254–56), included among the “Poems of Sentiment and Reflection” (see Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 168; see also Dearden, The Library of John Ruskin, 366 [no. 2916]).

Unusually, in this case, Ruskin shares octosyllabic couplets with Wordsworth rather than with Scott, whose lines are alexandrines, rhymed in an octave pattern of ABABCCCB, a stanza more commonly credited to Algernon Swinburne (e.g., in “The Garden of Proserpine”; I am grateful to my colleague, Alison Pelegrin, for help researching this verse form). However, in swerving to a meditative voice (“I thought as, by the cross I past”), Ruskinʼs narrator is indebted less to Wordsworth than to Scott, whose speaker pauses atop Helvellyn to contemplate the spot where the traveler fell: “I climbʼd the dark brow of the mighty Hellvellyn / . . . / When I markʼd the sad spot where the wanderer had died” (Poetical Works of Sir Walter Scott, 6:370). Possible lexical borrowings from both Scottʼs and Wordsworthʼs poems are noted in the textual glosses.

In his version of the “Account”, W. G. Collingwood omitted the entire second half of Ruskinʼs holograph poem containing the story of Gough and his faithful dog. Collingwood neither acknowledges nor provides a rationale for the omission; presumably, the storyʼs presence jarred with the editorʼs conception of the work as a long topographical account of the Tour of 1833. (He omitted all prose except what he interpolated himself, in the form of epigraphs quoting Ruskinʼs narrative version of the tour written a half‐century later for Praeterita. Given this emphasis, he was perhaps particularly annoyed by the inclusion of a tale set in the Lake District, rather than in the Alps.) In this decision, however, Collingwood eliminated evidence of one of Ruskinʼs most specific debts to the influence of Samuel Rogersʼs Italy, which uses narrative to plot emotions defining the stages of a mountain crossing. See the contextual glosses for “Passing the Alps”.
“StridenS ridgy range” (MS VIII; Works [1903])—Striding Edge, a ridge flanking Helvellyn.

“And died, beside a small dark tarn” (MS VIII; Works [1903])—Red Tarn, a small lake on the eastern flank of Helvellyn, below Striding Edge. In “Fidelity”, Wordsworth glosses tarn as “a small Mere or Lake, mostly high up in the mountains” (Poetical Works of William Wordsworth, 4:255n).
